resource.chars:
40.  In the specimen represented in Fig 2, the central portion appears
to have been lost, with  about a third of the peripheral; and the new
growth seems to have taken place at the same time from the
inner margin <u>a a a</u> of the fragment, and from its <u>outer</u>  margin <u>b b b</u>,
the two growths becoming continuous with each other along the
broken edges <u>ab ab</u>. For although the zones that lie internally
to <u>a a a</u> are conformable to those which surround them, yet there
is a peculiar character about them (more apparent in the specimen
than in the drawing) which indicates them to have been formed
at a late period, and to have been contemporaneous with those
which surround the zone <u>b b b</u>. Their actual continuity at the
angles <u>a a</u> is unfortunately interrupted by an injury which the specimen
seems subsequently to have received; yet its traces are sufficiently
perceptible on one side, to justify the  belief in its former existence.
_ The specimen of which Fig 1 is a delineation, seems to have
been the subject of several minor fractures and reparations; but
the course of its zones marks-out an obvious separation between
an earlier- and a later-formed portion, one having sprung from the
other<s>s</s> along the line <u>a.a</u>. The incompleteness of the specimen, however,
